summary.title: Computer Organization

AND.other: A grade of C- or better in CIS-2025, CIS-2262, or 2271 is required

summary.description: Students gain a basic understanding of computer hardware. The students are introduced to binary data representation, pointers and memory through the C language. This understanding expands to include the functioning of the CPU, including registers, ALU and simple I/O, culminating in an introduction to assembly language.

course-outcomes.outcome: Write simple programs in the C programming language.
Write simple functions in assembly language.
Describe the functioning of and work effectively with pointers and modern memory layout.
Identify and describe the components of the central processing unit of a computer.

laboratory-studio-outcomes.outcome: Use standard programming tools to compile and link C programs.
Use standard programming tools to examine and understand the assembly language generated by C programs
Use standard programming tools to compile assembly language functions and link them with C programs
Identify basic hardware components and perform basic maintenance operations, such as installing or upgrading memory DIMMs, disk drives, or PCI cards.

laboratory-studio-content.summary: Most of the lab time will be spent on either C or assembly language programming. At least some labs will be dedicated to hands-on hardware work.

outline.internal-comments: The lab will need access to a handful of (4 or so) non-vital (i.e. replaceable) computers for students to insert and remove parts. They need not be still useful speed-wise and could be machines being otherwise retired.
